div.head: Summary
div.p: In this sūtra, Buddha Śākyamuni teaches, at the request of Maitreya, five qualities that bodhisattvas should possess: (1) teaching the Dharma, (2) granting fearlessness, (3) practicing great loving kindness, great compassion, great joy, and great equanimity, (4) repairing old stūpas, and (5) causing all beings to aspire for the mind of awakening. Maitreya praises the benefits of this teaching and vows to teach it again in the future during degenerate times. Both Maitreya and the Buddha emphasize the positive effects on beings and the environment that comes about by upholding, preserving, and teaching The Nectar of Speech.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This text was translated from the Tibetan, introduced, and edited by the Dharmasāgara Translation Group: Raktrul Ngawang Kunga Rinpoche, Rebecca Hufen, Shanshan Jia, Jason Sanche, and Arne Schelling. Prof. Harunaga Isaacson (University of Hamburg) kindly assisted the translators with help and advice. The final version was also lightly edited by the 84000 editorial team. The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.

The Nectar of Speech is a Mahāyāna sūtra in which the Buddha Śākyamuni, at the request of the bodhisattva Maitreya, teaches a great assembly of monks and bodhisattvas. The setting for the teaching is the famous Veṇuvana forest monastery. This monastery was located outside of Rājagṛha, the capital city of Magadha, which at the time was one of the great kingdoms of ancient India (located in the modern-day state of Bihar). The teaching provides an outline of the following five qualities that bodhisattvas should possess in order to avert obstacles, prolong their lifespans, and attain awakening: Bodhisattvas should (1) teach the Dharma; (2) grant fearlessness; (3) practice great loving kindness, great compassion, great joy, and great equanimity; (4) repair old stūpas; and (5) cause all beings to aspire for the mind of awakening. After the Buddha finishes his main teaching, a large number of the monks, bodhisattvas, and celestial beings in attendance attain different stages of realization. Maitreya is inspired to give a discourse on the benefits of this sūtra and vows to teach it again in the future during the time of degeneration. His elaborations and his commitment are welcomed and endorsed by the Buddha. At the end, the Buddha emphasizes the importance of this teaching and instructs Ānanda to uphold and preserve it. The Buddha names the teaching The Nectar of Speech and also gives the alternative title of The Inquiry of Maitreya. In the standard formulaic style of ending a sūtra, the entire assembly rejoices and praises the words of the Buddha.

At present we are not aware of any Sanskrit version, Chinese translation, or any other rendering in other languages. The Tibetan versions across different Kangyurs list various Sanskrit titles, namely Amṛtavyāharaṇa (Degé), Amṛtadāna (Narthang), and Amṛtavarṇa (Stok). According to the colophon, the Tibetan translation was carried out by the Indian scholar Prajñāvarman and the Tibetan translator Yeshé Dé. It can therefore be assumed that the translation was produced in the late eighth or early ninth century ce in central Tibet. The text was cited by the contemporary Tibetan translator Kawa Paltsek (Toh 4357) and listed in the Denkarma catalogue, Denkarma, folio 299.b. See also Hermann-Pfandt (2008), p. 114, no. 215. which confirms that the translation of this sūtra into Tibetan must have been carried out prior to 812 ce. This English translation has been produced based on the Tibetan rendering that is found in the Degé Kangyur as well as the Comparative Edition (Tib. dpe bsdur ma) and the Stok Palace manuscript.
Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Thus did I hear at one time. The Bhagavān was residing in Rājagṛha at Veṇuvana in Kalandaka­nivāsa with a great saṅgha of five hundred bhikṣus and a great saṅgha of seventy-two thousand bodhisattvas. At that time the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya was also seated in the assembly. Then bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya rose from his seat, draped his upper robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, and with palms joined bowed to the Bhagavān and said, “With permission, I would like to ask the Blessed, thus-gone, worthy, perfect Buddha some questions.”

The Bhagavān replied, “Maitreya, the Tathāgata will always grant you permission. Maitreya, ask the Thus-Gone, worthy, perfect Buddha whatever you wish, and I shall ease your mind by answering each of your questions.”

The bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya then asked the Bhagavān: “Bhagavān, how many qualities do bodhisattva mahāsattvas need to possess so that no class of māra will cause them obstacles, so that none of the retinue of Māra will transgress against them, so that they will prolong their lifespans out of their love for sentient beings, and so that they will soon fully awaken to unexcelled and perfect awakening?”

The Bhagavān replied the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya, “Maitreya, excellent, excellent! Maitreya, your intention in asking the Thus-Gone, worthy, perfect Buddha about this matter is excellent, since you act for the benefit of many beings, aim for the happiness of many beings, have compassion for the world, and seek the welfare, benefit, and well-being of gods and humans. Hence, Maitreya, listen very well and keep it in mind! I will explain it.”
The bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya replied, “I will do so.”

He listened accordingly and the Bhagavān taught him: “Maitreya, if bodhisattva mahāsattvas are endowed with five particular qualities, no class of māra will cause them obstacles, none of the retinue of Māra will transgress against them, they will prolong their lifespans out of their love for sentient beings, and they will soon fully awaken to unexcelled and perfect awakening. What are these five? They are the unceasing teaching of the Dharma; the unceasing granting of fearlessness; the unceasing practice of great love, great compassion, great joy, and great equanimity; the unceasing repair of old stūpas; and the unceasing inspiration of all beings to set their minds on awakening. Kawa Paltsek (folio 283.b) quotes this passage as follows: “When bodhisattvas are endowed with five qualities, they will not be harmed by Māra, they will live long, and they will soon attain awakening. These five are (1) always teaching the Dharma to sentient beings, (2) granting fearlessness to sentient beings, (3) practicing the four immeasurable qualities, (4) repairing old stūpas, and (5) causing all beings to aspire for the mind of awakening.” Maitreya, if bodhisattva mahāsattvas are endowed with these five qualities, no class of māra will cause them obstacles, none of the retinue of Māra will transgress against them, they will prolong their lifespans out of their love for sentient beings, and they will soon fully awaken to unexcelled and perfect awakening.”

When the Bhagavān taught this discourse on the five qualities, the minds of five thousand bhikṣus became free of all defilements without remainder. Seventy-two thousand bodhisattvas attained the acceptance that phenomena do not arise. The eye of Dharma of eighty-four thousand gods became purified regarding phenomena, free from dust and stains, and without defilements.
Then the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya said to the Bhagavān: “Bhagavān, I feel inspired to speak. Blissful One, I feel inspired to speak.”
The Bhagavān said, “Noble son, speak if you think the time has come.”

Thereupon, with the permission of the Bhagavān, the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya rose from his seat, draped his upper robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, and with palms joined bowed to the Bhagavān and said, “Bhagavān, this Dharma discourse cures the illnesses of the afflictions of all beings who are sick from desire, anger, and ignorance and are obscured by the darkness of the cataracts and visual aberrations of all views. It purifies the unexcelled eye of Dharma. How marvelous! Bhagavān, this Dharma discourse is a great nectar! Bhagavān, this Dharma discourse is a great panacea! Even if born as an animal, those who hear this Dharma discourse will have gathered an accumulation of great roots of virtue and will be superior to all beings. They will behold all buddhas. They will be of great service to many beings. They will bring about roots of virtue. They will purify their karmic obscurations, become liberated from the animal realm, and attain human bodies. Then, remembering their previous lifetimes and gaining faith in the teachings of the Tathāgata, they can be reborn in any buddha realm they wish. If this is so, then what need is there to mention those who hear this while human?

“Bhagavān, hearing this Dharma discourse is of great benefit to beings. Bhagavān, beings who hear this Dharma discourse belong to the assembly of those who are certain to fully awaken to unexcelled and perfect awakening. Respected Bhagavān, because they will be embraced by the thus-gone, worthy, perfect buddhas, they will soon fully awaken to unexcelled and perfect awakening.”

The Bhagavān said, “Excellent, Maitreya, excellent! Maitreya, it is just as you have said. It is the truth. It is only this. It is unmistaken. If even those who listen with doubts to this Dharma discourse have no small roots of virtue, then what need is there to mention those who listen to, retain, hold, read, master, and teach it extensively and properly without any doubts? Such sūtra holders will not encounter the works of Māra. They will not be harmed by desire, anger, ignorance, pride, avarice, rage, or malevolence. Their bodies will not be stricken by plague or disease. In whatever place such a sūtra is kept, wherever such a Dharma teacher dwells, or wherever this Dharma discourse is written down as a scripture—in such places all diseases, epidemics, harm, contagions, and conflicts will be quelled.”

Then the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya said to the Bhagavān, “Bhagavān, later, in the future, during the final five hundred years when the true Dharma is disappearing and the time of destruction has come with the great fear that the Buddha’s awakening will vanish, I shall teach this Dharma discourse to those noble beings. I shall invigorate them. In places where a holder of this sūtra resides, I shall quell all untimely cold winds, winter rains, famine, diseases, plagues, epidemics, infectious disease, harm, and conflict. In a place where this Dharma discourse is kept and written down as a scripture or tied at the top of a banner and worshiped—in such a place, all the terrors of hostile armies, thieves, rākṣasas, and ḍākinīs will be quelled through my blessing. I shall bless those places where such Dharma teachers reside and where this sūtra is kept, so that all harvests, riches, grains, flowers, leaves, and fruits may be abundant, and all kinds of joy may arise.”

The Bhagavān said, “Excellent, Maitreya! It is excellent indeed that you have donned the great armor and proclaimed the lion’s roar for the benefit of all beings in order to uphold the true Dharma of the Tathāgata and to sustain Translated based on S: bskyang. D: bskyed. the Dharma way of the Tathāgata. I entrust this Dharma discourse to you. Thereby, later, in the future, during the final five hundred years when the true Dharma is disappearing and the time of destruction has come with the great fear that the Buddha’s awakening will vanish, you should teach this Dharma discourse to all beings. You should proclaim it. You should inspire those noble beings. You should proclaim that they must do nothing else but persevere in taking ultimate reality as their authority. You should teach them only according to the ultimate reality. You should be sure to teach them in such a way that those noble beings understand this Dharma discourse unmistakably as it is.”
The bodhisattva Maitreya said, “Bhagavān, I will do so.”

Thereupon Indra and his retinue of gods, Brahmā and his retinue of gods, Prajāpati, and others, after realizing that this Dharma discourse was coming to an end, offered heavenly flowers, fragrant smoke, incense, flower garlands, ointments, powders, garments, parasols, banners, and flags to the Bhagavān and the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya. They then exclaimed: “Bhagavān, this Dharma discourse that benefits innumerable beings is indeed a marvelous nectar of speech!”

Then the Bhagavān said to Venerable Ānanda, “Ānanda, such a Dharma discourse is rarely heard. Therefore, you must retain this Dharma discourse. You must write it down, hold it, read it aloud, and master it!”
Ānanda said, “Bhagavān, I will retain this Dharma discourse. Bhagavān, what is the name of this Dharma discourse? How should it be remembered?”
The Bhagavan said, “Ānanda, you should remember this Dharma discourse as The Nectar of Speech. You should also refer to it as The Inquiry of Maitreya.”

After the Bhagavān had spoken thus, the entire assembly—Venerable Ānanda, the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya, the bhikṣus, the bodhisattvas, and also the gods, humans, asuras, and gandharvas— rejoiced and praised the words of the Bhagavān.
div.trailer: This concludes the noble Mahāyāna sūtra called “The Nectar of Speech.”

gloss.term: acceptance that phenomena do not arise
mi skye ba’i chos la bzod pa
The particular realization that all phenomena are beyond birth.

Epithet of the Buddha. In Sanskrit usually defined as someone who is the possessor of six specific qualities as well as the conqueror of māras. The usual definition of the Tibetan term is bcom (“subdue”), referring to the subduing of the four māras; ldan (“to possess”), referring to the possession of the great qualities of buddhahood; and ’das (“beyond,” “transcended”), meaning that such a person has gone beyond saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.

Originally the name of Indra’s principal enemy among the asuras. In early Buddhism he appears as a drought-causing demon and eventually his name becomes that of Māra, the principal opponent of the Buddha's teaching. The name also applies to the deities ruled over by Māra who attempted to prevent the Buddha’s awakening and who do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra.
The wish, resolve, and practice to attain complete awakening for the sake of all sentient beings.
Epithet of the Buddha. Also rendered here as “Thus-Gone.”
Epithet of the Buddha. Also rendered here as “Tathāgata.”
Depending on the etymological interpretation, “worthy one” or “a person who has defeated the enemy of the afflictions (kleśa).”
Name of a first cousin, close student, and attendant of the Buddha.
A famous Tibetan translator and monk of the 8th–9th centuries.
Name of a bodhisattva who it is believed will be the future buddha after Śākyamuni, becoming the fifth buddha of this eon.

An Indian scholar and translator of the 8th–9th centuries who translated, in collaboration with other Indian and Tibetan scholars, about eighty texts of the Kangyur into Tibetan. He also composed commentaries that are preserved in the Tengyur.
A famous Tibetan translator and monk of the 8th–9th centuries, who translated and revised in collaboration with various Indian scholars more than 250 texts of the Kangyur and Tengyur into Tibetan.
bya ka lan da ka gnas pa

Literally, “The Squirrel Feeding Ground.” A location within Veṇuvana where the Buddha stayed. The place received its name from the many flying squirrels living there, being fed by humans. It should be noted that Tibetan translations understand the Sanskrit term kalandaka to refer to a kind of bird.
Situated in the modern Indian state of Bihar, Rājagṛha was the capital of Magadha, one of the great kingdoms of ancient India.
King Bimbisāra’s park (lit. “Bamboo Grove”) near Rājagṛha. Here the Buddha dwelled regularly and gave many teachings.
